<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
LEGAL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/28/businesses-seek-protection-covid19-lawsuits?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
What Are You Gonna Do, Sue Me?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Store in a bubble" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83NDMvc3RvcmVfaW5fYV9idWJibGUuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">A handful of U.S. states started easing economic restrictions this week, but businesses are worried their "all employees must wash hands—we actually mean that" signs won't cut it as the world's most litigious population peeps aboveground. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Last week, U.S. Chamber of Commerce head Suzanne Clark told Axios that businesses are <a href="https://nypost.com/2020/04/24/businesses-fear-lawsuits-amid-coronavirus-reopening/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">anxious</a> about a wave of lawsuits from customers and workers who contract COVID-19. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Time for torts </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Customers and employees can sue a business for lost wages, medical expenses, and other damages <em>if</em> they prove negligence, recklessness, or intentional disregard for their safety. But some recommended precautions for COVID-19 could <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/28/business/businesses-coronavirus-liability.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">run up against</a> workplace protection laws, such as:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Telling other employees when someone is sick (privacy violation)</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Requiring workers to test negative before coming back (discrimination and health privacy)</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Prohibiting at-risk populations like the elderly from coming to work (more discrimination)</span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Who's taking care of this? </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Last week, President Trump said his administration was <a href="https://www.politico.com/news/2020/04/22/larry-kudlow-businesses-coronavirus-infections-201026?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">exploring ways</a> to help shield businesses. But experts think Congress needs to tap its interstate commerce regulatory powers for any meaningful changes. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Congress already capped liability for businesses making desperately needed masks. Manufacturers have proposed extending those protections to other companies making PPE and essential items.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Some labor unions and Democratic leaders are pushing back, arguing that weakened labor protections would let employers skate by without providing basic protections. Numerous complaints have been filed over unsafe conditions for essential workers.  </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) has </span><span><a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/2020/04/28/coronavirus-can-you-sue-if-you-get-covid-19-work/3035422001/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">received</a></span><span> 4,000 complaints against employers related to coronavirus but hasn't issued any citations or fines, a labor leader told USA Today.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>the Senate resumes its session Monday, and Majority Leader Mitch McConnell wants to pass liability protections before tackling new relief packages. That might set up a fight with Democrats, who want billions for states, cities, and frontline workers.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
EARNINGS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/28/tuesday-earnings-reveal-major-business-trends-amid-pandemic?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
What's Up, What's Down
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">50 years from now, some Gen ZZer is going to ask what life was like during the coronavirus pandemic of 2020. Show them this roundup of yesterday's quarterly earnings reports. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">What's up </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000"><img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/upwards-black-arrow_2b06.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> Personal safety gear: </strong>3M, the maker of the N95 mask, said demand for food safety products and cleaning supplies was to thank for <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-28/3m-relies-on-more-than-just-face-masks-to-get-through-pandemic?sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">better-than-expected sales</a> last quarter.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000"><img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/upwards-black-arrow_2b06.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> The economy before COVID-19: </strong>Google parent Alphabet reported a strong first two months of 2020 before a "<a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/04/28/alphabet-googl-earnings-q1-2020.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">significant slowdown</a> in ad revenues" in March. The company still beat revenue estimates.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">What's down </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000"><img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/downwards-black-arrow_2b07.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> Construction: </strong>Dad-approved heavy equipment maker Caterpillar reported a <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/04/28/caterpillar-cat-earnings-q1-2020.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">21% drop</a> in Q1 sales due to "lower end user demand." About 75% of its primary production facilities are currently operating. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000"><img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/downwards-black-arrow_2b07.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> New car smell: </strong>Ford posted a <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ford-motor-results/ford-posts-2-billion-first-quarter-loss-due-to-coronavirus-idUSKCN22A1CX?feedType=RSS&feedName=businessNews&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">$2 billion loss</a> in Q1 and expects that to more than double in Q2. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000"><img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/downwards-black-arrow_2b07.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> Doctor's visits: </strong>Drugmaker Merck expects the coronavirus to slice $2.1 billion off 2020 sales. Merck's CFO said <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-merck-co-results/merck-sees-2-1-billion-coronavirus-hit-to-2020-sales-idUSKCN22A1M9?feedType=RSS&feedName=businessNews&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">two-thirds of its products</a> are administered by physicians. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000"><img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/downwards-black-arrow_2b07.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""> Awkward boarding interactions: </strong>Southwest Airlines reported its <a href="https://apnews.com/b3ce0bed911bc20569cd187fabba256c?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">first quarterly loss</a> since 2011.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ENTERTAINMENT
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/28/trolls-sequel-reportedly-brings-96-million-digital-release?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Universal Trolls the Box Office
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="DreamWorks" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yMzUvdHJvbGxzLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Universal</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><em>Trolls </em>sequel <em>Trolls World Tour </em>raked in about $95 million in fees from almost 5 million digital rentals in just three weeks, according to <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/trolls-world-tour-breaks-digital-records-and-charts-a-new-path-for-hollywood-11588066202?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">the WSJ.</a></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>That’s more than the original made in five months in theaters. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory: </strong>Studios and theaters were tussling over releases way before the pandemic struck. Theaters insisted on exclusive screening rights for at least two months before movies could debut at home, while Netflix insisted times have changed. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Universal gets to keep about 80% of digital rental and purchase fees, compared to 50% of box office sales. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The pandemic and theater closures gave studio execs the opportunity to try something they’d been eyeing for a while—”PVOD,” or premium video on demand. <em>Trolls World Tour </em>dropped on April 10 on platforms like Apple TV, Xfinity, and Amazon Prime. It was so successful, NBCUniversal CEO Jeff Shell told the WSJ that after the pandemic, the studio would release movies both in-theater and via PVOD. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">That poked the bears. </strong>AMC Theatres, the biggest chain in the world, <a href="https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/amc-theatres-refuses-play-universal-films-wake-trolls-world-tour-1292327?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">said last night</a> it would stop playing any of Universal's films. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"></p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">
<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F04%2F28%2Ftrolls-sequel-reportedly-brings-96-million-digital-release" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">
<img alt="" style="display: inline-block; width: 25px" width="25" src="https://media.sailthru.com/5z8/1k4/4/2/5e865734bf6f7.jpg">
</a><span>  </span>
<a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=It+out-earned+the+original+in+just+three+weeks+&url=https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/28/trolls-sequel-reportedly-brings-96-million-digital-release&via=MorningBrew" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">
<img alt="" style="display: inline-block; width: 25px" width="25" src="https://media.sailthru.com/5z8/1k4/4/2/5e86574d1eb82.jpg">
</a><span>  </span>

<img alt="" style="display: inline-block; width: 25px" width="25" src="https://media.sailthru.com/5z8/1k4/4/2/5e86576e04837.jpg">
</a><span>  </span>

</a>
</td>

</h3>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We’re not trying to make something like the stock market more complicated than it already is, so we’ll just come out and say this:</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The Motley Fool has doubled down</strong> on <a href="https://www.fool.com/mms/mark/double-down-2?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=contentmarketing&utm_campaign=sar-doubledown2&aid=9187&paid=9187&waid=9187&source=esamnbwdg0210074&psource=esamnbwdg0210074&wsource=esamnbwdg0210074" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">this one stock</a>.</p>

<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">

</h1>

</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, the owner of the High Times cannabis magazine <a href="https://www.mercurynews.com/2020/04/28/high-times-owner-scores-13-california-marijuana-dispensaries/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">announced plans</a> to buy 13 California dispensaries from Harvest Health, one of the country’s largest distributors. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The short-term angle: </strong>The pandemic has been tough on publishing—High Times temporarily suspended two of its publications and laid off staff due to supply chain issues. But demand for cannabis is stronger than ever under lockdown. Sales were up 159% annually by mid-March, according to Headset. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The long-term angle: </strong>The legal cannabis market will grow from almost $11 billion globally in 2018 to a projected $50 billion by 2029, provided 2029 still happens, says Jefferies. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>A group of investors bought the 46-year-old High Times in 2017 and have been working to position cannabis as a high-end product. Their push into retail began in January with plans for two flagship stores in LA and Las Vegas. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>the companies plan to close the deal by June 30.</p>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
CITIES
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/28/lithuania-turns-capital-open-air-cafe?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Cities Dig up Their Jean Shorts
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="New York City" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83NDQvbmV3X3lvcmtfY2l0eS5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Publicdomainpictures.net</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Public health authorities say we need to maintain social distancing to keep the coronavirus in check. But the world's municipal leaders know that spring is springing, and that means people will leave their homes.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius, cafés and restaurants will be allowed to <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/apr/28/lithuanian-capital-to-be-turned-into-vast-open-air-cafe-vilnius?CMP=Share_iOSApp_Other&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">set up tables</a> in public areas. While the government has permitted those businesses to reopen with outdoor seating, in some narrow-streeted neighborhoods it's not possible to operate in accordance with social distancing rules. So Mayor Remigijus Šimašius said plazas, squares, and streets are temporarily fair game for next-level al fresco dining. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Back here in NYC, the City Council had a similar brain blast. This week, the de Blasio administration said the city will <a href="https://ny.curbed.com/2020/4/27/21238276/nyc-coronavirus-opens-100-miles-streets-pedestrians-biking?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">open up</a> at least 40 miles of streets to pedestrians and cyclists to promote social distancing among New Yorkers in our finest spring attire (all black, but with a hat). </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">We know you're wondering...</strong>is city life even possible during the pandemic? Short answer: Yes, but different city life. Longer answer: You'll find that in our <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/24/future-cities#utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Future of Cities</a> series.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ Friday quiz preview:</strong> We will ask you to name the capital of Lithuania. Not its mayor, don't worry. </p>

</h3>
</td>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">

<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Normally when we write “trivia,” we don’t literally mean “information of little value or importance.” With today’s question, we actually do mean it.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">While going down a UFO Wikipedia rabbit hole (after those <a href="https://www.theregister.co.uk/2020/04/27/dod_ufo_video/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">videos</a> were released), we encountered a slang term that was used by Allied pilots in WWII to describe strange objects they saw flying around the skies. A famous rock band named itself after this two-word term. What’s the band?</p>

collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eA handful of U.S. states started easing economic restrictions this week, but businesses are worried their \"all employees must wash hands—we actually mean that\" signs won't cut it as the world's most litigious population peeps aboveground. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLast week, U.S. Chamber of Commerce head Suzanne Clark told Axios that businesses are \u003ca href=\"https://nypost.com/2020/04/24/businesses-fear-lawsuits-amid-coronavirus-reopening/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eanxious\u003c/a\u003e about a wave of lawsuits from customers and workers who contract COVID-19. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eTime for torts \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eCustomers and employees can sue a business for lost wages, medical expenses, and other damages \u003cem\u003eif\u003c/em\u003e they prove negligence, recklessness, or intentional disregard for their safety. But some recommended precautions for COVID-19 could \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/28/business/businesses-coronavirus-liability.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erun up against\u003c/a\u003e workplace protection laws, such as:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eTelling other employees when someone is sick (privacy violation)\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eRequiring workers to test negative before coming back (discrimination and health privacy)\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eProhibiting at-risk populations like the elderly from coming to work (more discrimination)\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWho's taking care of this? \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLast week, President Trump said his administration was \u003ca href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2020/04/22/larry-kudlow-businesses-coronavirus-infections-201026?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eexploring ways\u003c/a\u003e to help shield businesses. But experts think Congress needs to tap its interstate commerce regulatory powers for any meaningful changes. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eCongress already capped liability for businesses making desperately needed masks. Manufacturers have proposed extending those protections to other companies making PPE and essential items.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSome labor unions and Democratic leaders are pushing back, arguing that weakened labor protections would let employers skate by without providing basic protections. Numerous complaints have been filed over unsafe conditions for essential workers.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) has \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/2020/04/28/coronavirus-can-you-sue-if-you-get-covid-19-work/3035422001/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereceived\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e 4,000 complaints against employers related to coronavirus but hasn't issued any citations or fines, a labor leader told USA Today.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ethe Senate resumes its session Monday, and Majority Leader Mitch McConnell wants to pass liability protections before tackling new relief packages. That might set up a fight with Democrats, who want billions for states, cities, and frontline workers.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eUniversal\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eTrolls \u003c/em\u003esequel \u003cem\u003eTrolls World Tour \u003c/em\u003eraked in about $95 million in fees from almost 5 million digital rentals in just three weeks, according to \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/trolls-world-tour-breaks-digital-records-and-charts-a-new-path-for-hollywood-11588066202?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ethe WSJ.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThat’s more than the original made in five months in theaters. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory: \u003c/strong\u003eStudios and theaters were tussling over releases way before the pandemic struck. Theaters insisted on exclusive screening rights for at least two months before movies could debut at home, while Netflix insisted times have changed. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eUniversal gets to keep about 80% of digital rental and purchase fees, compared to 50% of box office sales. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe pandemic and theater closures gave studio execs the opportunity to try something they’d been eyeing for a while—”PVOD,” or premium video on demand. \u003cem\u003eTrolls World Tour \u003c/em\u003edropped on April 10 on platforms like Apple TV, Xfinity, and Amazon Prime. It was so successful, NBCUniversal CEO Jeff Shell told the WSJ that after the pandemic, the studio would release movies both in-theater and via PVOD. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThat poked the bears. \u003c/strong\u003eAMC Theatres, the biggest chain in the world, \u003ca href=\"https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/amc-theatres-refuses-play-universal-films-wake-trolls-world-tour-1292327?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esaid last night\u003c/a\u003e it would stop playing any of Universal's films. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, the owner of the High Times cannabis magazine \u003ca href=\"https://www.mercurynews.com/2020/04/28/high-times-owner-scores-13-california-marijuana-dispensaries/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eannounced plans\u003c/a\u003e to buy 13 California dispensaries from Harvest Health, one of the country’s largest distributors. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe short-term angle: \u003c/strong\u003eThe pandemic has been tough on publishing—High Times temporarily suspended two of its publications and laid off staff due to supply chain issues. But demand for cannabis is stronger than ever under lockdown. Sales were up 159% annually by mid-March, according to Headset. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe long-term angle: \u003c/strong\u003eThe legal cannabis market will grow from almost $11 billion globally in 2018 to a projected $50 billion by 2029, provided 2029 still happens, says Jefferies. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eA group of investors bought the 46-year-old High Times in 2017 and have been working to position cannabis as a high-end product. Their push into retail began in January with plans for two flagship stores in LA and Las Vegas. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ethe companies plan to close the deal by June 30.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-top: 12px;\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F04%2F28%2Fhigh-times-magazine-owner-buy-13-ca-dispensaries\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"\" style=\"display: inline-block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83NDQvbmV3X3lvcmtfY2l0eS5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003ePublicdomainpictures.net\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePublic health authorities say we need to maintain social distancing to keep the coronavirus in check. But the world's municipal leaders know that spring is springing, and that means people will leave their homes.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius, cafés and restaurants will be allowed to \u003ca href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/apr/28/lithuanian-capital-to-be-turned-into-vast-open-air-cafe-vilnius?CMP=Share_iOSApp_Other\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eset up tables\u003c/a\u003e in public areas. While the government has permitted those businesses to reopen with outdoor seating, in some narrow-streeted neighborhoods it's not possible to operate in accordance with social distancing rules. So Mayor Remigijus Šimašius said plazas, squares, and streets are temporarily fair game for next-level al fresco dining. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBack here in NYC, the City Council had a similar brain blast. This week, the de Blasio administration said the city will \u003ca href=\"https://ny.curbed.com/2020/4/27/21238276/nyc-coronavirus-opens-100-miles-streets-pedestrians-biking?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eopen up\u003c/a\u003e at least 40 miles of streets to pedestrians and cyclists to promote social distancing among New Yorkers in our finest spring attire (all black, but with a hat). \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWe know you're wondering...\u003c/strong\u003eis city life even possible during the pandemic? Short answer: Yes, but different city life. Longer answer: You'll find that in our \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/24/future-cities#utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eFuture of Cities\u003c/a\u003e series.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e+ Friday quiz preview:\u003c/strong\u003e We will ask you to name the capital of Lithuania.
